div.p:
—Amidst the plains
of North America, some powerful nation, which has disap-
peared, constructed circular, square, and octagonal fortifi-
cations: walls, 6000 toises in length; tumuli, from 700 to 800
feet in diameter, and 140 feet in height, sometimes round,
with several stories, and containing thousands of skeletons.
These skeletons are less slender and more squat than the
present inhabitants of those countries. On a vast space of
ground on the Lower Orinoco, as well as on the banks of the
Cassiquaire, and between the sources of the Essequibo and
Rio Branco, there are rocks of granite covered with symbolic
figures. These sculptures denote that the extinct generation
belonged to nations different from those which now inhabit
the same regions.—Humboldt’s Travels.
